comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From this exterior shot in the nli archive, this hotel looks to be the Ramada Hotel today. The OSNI maps of 1896 and 1904 says it is the Northern Counties Hotel. it isn't there at all on the 1853 map. Aha, from a Wikipedia article on the Northern Counties Committee railway: The BNCR purchased a share in the lease of the long standing and well thought of Antrim Arms hotel at Portrush and in 1883 formed a separate company to manage what was renamed the Northern Counties Hotel

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: The Antrim Arms was renamed the Northern Counties Hotel in the 1880s (after being acquired by the Belfast & Northern Counties Railway Company in 1881). A quick search for "Northern Counties" throws up a number of nice old pics of Portrush and among them this dining room image (which looks the same as "your one" Carol). So I'd say the label is right. I wonder if the date is right though? Given the renaming could the date be earlier?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: From Wiki The BNCR purchased a share in the lease of the long standing and well thought of Antrim Arms hotel at Portrush and in 1883 formed a separate company to manage what was renamed the Northern Counties Hotel. Situated on an elevated site, the hotel overlooked the Atlantic Ocean at front and back. With more than one hundred rooms, it was intended to accommodate high-class tourists visiting the Giant's Causeway. The hotel was enlarged and improved in 1884 and 1892 and in 1902 the BNCR purchased the freehold outright from the Earl of Antrim. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Counties_Committee

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I find that spending time looking at shots like this are very educational!  When you look at the table settings, the glassware has changed so much, the silverware has been replaced with stainless steel, the Irish Linen tablecloth and napkins by paper in most establishments and two bottles of bubbly on a table with no ice bucket?????  Interesting shot Carol, it certainly speaks of days gone by and a very different social order!

comment._content: If the food is as good as the setting, let me at it!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I think "that fantastic piece of furniture" is a what-not -
"A what-not is a piece of furniture derived from the French étagère, which was exceedingly popular in England in the first three-quarters of the 19th century. It usually consists of slender uprights or pillars, supporting a series of shelves for holding china, ornaments, trifles, or what not, hence the allusive name. In its English form, although a convenient piece of drawing room furniture, it was rarely beautiful. The early mahogany examples are, however, sometimes graceful in their simplicity."

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
From The Belfast News-Letter, Monday, September 30, 1861, in an article entitled PORTRUSH - GRAND BALL AT THE ANTRIM ARMS:
The close of the season in this popular watering place was celebrated by a ball, on a grand scale, on Wednesday night last. The company was composed of the rank and fashion of the neighbourhood, and the entertainment passed off with all the éclat of a "County Ball". Indeed, during the season the visitors at Portrush have been enjoying a complete round of gaieties - this is the third party of the same brilliant kind which assembled for a like purpose in the Coffee-room of the Antrim Arms. The designation is, however, by no means calculated to convey an adequate conception of the immense proportions of the apartment, which is as commodious in its dimensions, and far more tasteful in its adornments, that the assembly rooms of most provincial towns. Filled with the fashionably-dressed assemblage of Wednesday night, it was placed in the most advantageous light, and presented a tout ensemble of rare attractiveness.
There follows a description of dancing, or 'labyrinthine evolutions of the "mazy dance", then:
Supper of the most recherche description was laid about one o'clock. The excellence and variety of the viands were the theme of admiration, and testified to the taste and energy displayed in the conduct and management of the hotel by Mr Parsons.
There's then a very long list of names of the great and the good attending the ball, and a list of the dances. Finally,
Dancing was kept up with spirit and animation until the laggard sun of a September morning penetrated the Venetian blinds of the Coffee-room, and paled the brilliancy of the crystal chandeliers, which for hours had showered a dazzling stream of light on the most joyous and festive scene Portrush has yet witnessed.
Full article here.

comment._content: Sounds more like a rave club than a coffee room!
